Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Intelligent System for Dredging Projects operation and Management
Award.AbstractNarration:
The operation and management of a dredging project requires high-performance, expensive equipment and specialized resources. A typical dredging project represents approximately $1.2 million in value of production per day. Lack of optimal information flow between owners and contractors during dredging operations exacerbates the risk of diminished performance, errors, project delays, and contractor claims. As a solution to these problems, the concept of a Web-based Project Management System (WPMS) for dredging operations has been developed. Subsequently, a prototype of the system was created and it is currently undergoing evaluation by select potential customers. Government departments, port authorities, harbor operators, and dredging contractors have shown interest in the system. The Panama Canal Authority (PCA) dredging operations have become a testbed for further development of system specifications. The subsequent efforts will focus on developing the commercial grade when it can undergo full-scale testing and commercial evaluation. The Web-based Project Management System (WPMS) combines information system architecture with communication infrastructure technology to create an intelligent system for comprehensive information processing.

The dredging industry has a major influence on the performance of water-borne trade, and thus on the world's economic wealth. Additionally, it impacts marine and coastal ecosystems, thus affecting marine life and the natural environment in general. It is expected that after the deployment of the proposed sensor-based hardware on serviced dredging equipment, the proposed WPMS solution will be delivered to dredging industry customers on a software-as-a-service basis. Based on the team's prior investigations, it is further anticipated that the cost of performance of dredging operations may be reduced by approx. 20-30% or more after full implementation of the proposed WPMS. The team estimates that a minimum viable product ready to be tested on a dredge and with the specifications derived from the customer discovery can be achieved in 6 months from the date the I-Corps program starts. The funding, what the team will learn from the 100 interviews, and refining the prototype, are vital to the success and commercialization of the Intelligent Decision Support and Management System for Dredging.

POR.DRECONTENT:
PROJECT OUTCOMES REPORT

Title: I-Corps: Intelligent System for Dredging Projects operation and Management 

PI: Miroslaw Skibniewski 

Awardee: University of Maryland College Park 

Award Number: 1636458

Award Ends:07/31/2016

Program Officer Name: Lydia Mcclure

BACKGROUND

Current dredging projects are being hampered by claims, change orders, and errors generated by uncertainties due to lack of information sharing, incomplete information, lack of understanding of site conditions, lack of quality information, and extended learning curves, all of which lead to increased cost, duration, and lower quality of dredging projects, Our team at the University of Maryland, Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering is developing a web-based operations decision support system —an Intelligent System for Dredging, to improve dredging operations and management processes. The core objective of the system is to capture live dredge operating and programmatic data, transmit, archive, process it for analysis and reporting, and redistribute it to stakeholders in real-time for management and decision making. The data is captured, archived, analyzed, and reported using a combination of desktop, web-based technology, relational databases, and transmission Internet protocols. This system does not exist in the current market. If this proposal is funded our team will participate in the 7 weeks Innovation Corps Team Program.

 

PROGRAM OBJECTIVE

The objective was to learn the process to start a company using the “Lean Start-up” methodology, and using the hypothesis-validation, minimum viable product, and pivoting concepts. This would help us understand how to develop the product that customers want by using the concept of Value Proposition and Business Model using the Business Model Canvas. The course would introduce the program at the Kickoff meeting, continue with 100 interviews to potential customers, and end with a lessons learn meeting. This would help us understand the market need in relation to our technology, and if needed, make the necessary changes to the technology to fit the market or move to another segment of the market.

 

Intellectual Merit

During this program the team would continue the customer discovery process started at the UMD I-Corp by advancing our knowledge of the market and the customer discovery process. The 100 interviews would give us a comprehensive understanding of the market needs, and facilitate the creation of a Value Proposition through a strong correlation between our technology and the market segment. If we were able to create a Value Proposition that fit strongly with a market segment needs then we would form a company called INTELDREDGE to commercialize the Intelligent System for Dredging.

 

PROGRAM OUTCOME

The program was not completed by the team because, after one week into the program and shortly after the team came back from the program Kick-Off trip to Atlanta, the Entrepreneurial Lead (EL) became ill and could not continue with the program. The Program Officer granted permission to exit the program after a request from the team.

The Program reimbursed the Kick-Off trip expenses to the team:

Below is the amounts reported for reimbursement:

Miroslaw Skibniewski:                                  $2631.70

Pawel Szerszen:                                             $2,486.15

Gustavo Vecino:                                            $2,713.21

Gustavo Vecino:                                            $1,200.00

Total Approved for Reimbursement        $9,031.06

 

 


Last Modified: 01/26/2017
Modified by: Miroslaw J Skibniewski
